history.content:
Some say learning public speaking is good.

Listening is probably good too. 

For what its worth, sometimes those who have good social skills are ultimately less interesting than those who are more thoughtful about what they say. Indeed, at some point you realize they just repeat themselves without saying anything interesting.  In any case, I think confidence helps as well (which again may come from learning public speaking or listening enough to engage with someone meaningfully.)

In any case, what is an awkward encounter?  Perhaps review it and think about how it could have been different; perhaps the same situation comes up again, and you better navigate the situation. For example, did you have an "in" when you listened.   You have these experiences, thinking them through is probably a reasonable strategy. Presumably analytical skills can be applied here as well.  

Personally, I tend to obsess about everything including interactions and what might have been a better or more interesting way to address this situation or that; unfortunately, it is usually that "Oh, I wish I thought of saying that line."  On the other hand, one does occasionally hit the mark, even in my own very non-standard way of evaluating hitting the mark.  I think it is because the same situation  often comes up again.

I personally don't think our students should own a "lack of social skills".  Its just another problem to solve, an important one for world.  The seriousness and earnestness should not be lost in a world of chatter.

Then again, perhaps I am not the best one to offer advice on social skills.....

I guess I am laughing a little...

------------------------------------

Edit:  For an example of over-analysis.

Look at those last two lines.  It undermines the message here. That you really have properly identified a problem and that you should strive to address it.   My position as a professor is to support that.  But then I undermined my own position with those last two lines. Moreover, it is not particularly true.

This particular point though is common among CS people, I think especially very strong engineers.  They proceed with caution and humility.  I have to warn my teaching assistants against putting themselves down (perhaps even jokingly) in front of students.  Because it isn't true and its bad for student experience in that they may lose trust.

I agree on improv as well as the poster below suggests, but being thoughtful is maybe good too.

children.subject:
You know one thing that has helped many people I know develop communication skills is Toastmasters.  Been around for a long time and many local groups.

https://california.toastmasters.org/

I endorse theater. Best class I ever took in high school. We did improv as warm ups every class, game changer for me. If I had to pinpoint 1 course that really set the foundation for my confidence in myself, it was theater.

I also recommend being in skits and plays. I did everything from filmed comedy skits, to radio shows(we were in a booth reading out a story I think), monologue of smeagol/gollum, 2 person in love skit, 2 person breakup skit lol, Tim Burton-like skit, I even made my own 2 hour play. Many of these scenes were totally weird, but I loved doing them and that love really got me over not caring if others would judge or make fun of me for doing something I enjoyed doing or saying something I found funny/honest.

I think just joining these organizations suggested, if you can, could help out because the whole essence of these activities is socializing with others with the intent of improving your communication skills, whether it's body language, eye contact, posture, verbal, etc.

The most important thing about the class was my teacher had a ton of love and support for me. Being validated during improv and these plays, having that support from someone who excels in the field, made me feel like I am awesome and that I do have great communication skills(or I improved them so much during the class). So if you choose to take on improv, theater, or public speaking clubs, definitely stick with peers or an instructor who is really kind and encouraging.

With that being said, there were definitely people in my intro theater class who weren't feeling it, and that's okay. If you do join, put yourself out of your comfort zone. But if you find you don't like it and it's not helping, you're chillen.

Personally never taken a theater class at Cal, but maybe you can try out one of these classes, like Theater 10:

http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/theater/

Kind of a curveball, and trying not to sound like a plug, but I highly recommend theater, specifically improv theater. You're literally learning how to act human (or at least faking it), which can provide insight on how to manage social interactions.

For me, it's given me self-confidence for public speaking and conversation starting, and I've heard others say similar things. Eugene Chiang, an astro/EPS professor here, recently gave a talk and even mentioned how his minor in theater helped him communicate and navigate through the sciences.

I recommend improv theater because it helps you think quick on your feet and it's super fun. If you don't know what to say, improv theater will force you to say something, and then get better at saying something good. However any other type of basic theater training will get you comfortable with social skills also.

+1

As someone who has struggled with social anxiety throughout their high school and college years, I can confirm that this is wonderful advice. People love to talk about themselves. Thus, becoming comfortable asking questions and listening is very powerful. In fact, some of the most socially adept and influential people I know tend to talk about themselves very little.

Another thing I've come to understand is that it is very easy to fall into the trap of believing that others view/think about us in the same way that we do. I do not believe it is "1 to 1". For example, I might be working with in a lab with someone, and in my head I might think: Oh no I'm not saying anything, they must think I'm so awkward! What do I say? They are probably looking at me waiting for me to say something! The reality is probably quite the opposite. They are probably just thinking about the work at hand, or a relationship, or their company, or loved ones, etc.
+1 For more on this, check out "how to win friends and influence people" by Dale Carnegie.
Professor Dave Patterson (recent Turing award winner) highly recommends that book.

In general terms, just listening to people and asking about their lives and interest helps a lot. People love to talk about themselves and they'll think you're wonderful if you ask questions about them or things they're interested in and really listen to the answers. It can be something like--did you do anything interesting over the weekend?, or "I'm curious about x topic, can you explain it more/how did you get into it", etc.--make note of what they say, remember it, and bring it up later. Not only will people like you, but at the very least they will ask similar questions back and suddenly you're having a conversation. 

Someone once told me listen twice as much as you speak and I've tried to apply that in my career. I've learned so much and had a ton of amazing conversations with all sorts of people. Too many people equate social skills with speaking about yourself, in my mind, when it's more about being truly interested in others. If you have trouble remembering things about people, have a "little black book"-- first chance you get, write down that person's name and anything you learned about them. Just like class it helps it stick in your mind and you'll have a repository of facts and interests to fall back on and create conversation out of.
One resource that I've been using is succeedsocially.com. I haven't read every article on this website, but what I've read has been quite useful for me in terms of developing my social skills.

I just want to thank everyone for being so constructive and kind. I feel like this is the kind of question that generally attracts trolling but I'm glad it was taken seriously since its a sentiment that a lot of us share. I'll definitely be looking at the posted resources.

I also recommend becoming a mentor for CSM! Being a CSM mentor has not only solidified my understanding of the material but also improved my ability to communicate with different types of people and handle conflict.

history.content: After recently interning at a startup, I've come to realize that my social skills are extremely poor.. I suck at networking, and I've had more awkward encounters than I can count. I'm not nervous or anything, I just literally don't know what to say. I'm growing increasingly frustrated with this situation and was wondering how to improve?
history.subject: Completely lack social skills
